li.a: Bed Bugs, Ticks, and Other Insects
Family Resource Center (One Door to Pathways)
Bed Bugs, Ticks, and Other Insects
Family Resource Center (One Door to Pathways)

div.p: The situation with COVID-19 is rapidly changing. Please visit the following sources for the most updated information:
Ohio Department of Health (ODH) – Cases in Ohio updated at 2:00 p.m. daily
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) – U.S. case information updated at 12:00 noon daily Monday – Friday

p.br: Call the ODH Call Center at 1(833)4-ASK-ODH or 1(833)427-5634. Open 7 days a week from 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m

p.span: Concerns regarding compliance with the Ohio Stay at Home Order (Espanol) may be reported to COVID19@lcghd.org or (440)350-2188. Those who wish to remain anonymous are encouraged to report by phone.

hr.p: The LCGHD Business Enforcement Dashboard for the Ohio Stay at Home Order can be viewed here. (Note, the dashboard is better viewed on a larger screen.)

p.span: Due to an increased volume of inquiries and the need to consult with Ohio Department of Health and legal expertise, it may take up to 48 hours to respond and/or resolve a complaint.
We appreciate your continued patience during this challenging time.

hr.p:
This page will be regularly updated with any local information.
Most recent updates are in red.

span.b:
Total cases reported in Lake County to date*: 160
Total COVID-19 deaths reported in Lake County to date*: 7
Total cases reported in Ohio to date*: 16,769

b.br: Total COVID-19 deaths reported in Ohio to date*: 799

p.em: *Please note these numbers reflect those reported by ODH at 2:00 p.m. daily, and actual numbers may vary. As of 4/10/2020 these numbers include both laboratory confirmed and probable cases under the expanded CDC case definition.

div.p: The most up-to-date number of cases in Ohio and counties with confirmed cases are available at coronavirus.ohio.gov.

p.span: Daily updates are posted below.
Dr. Acton reported that Ohio has 16,769 cases and 799 deaths due to COVID-19. All 88 counties in Ohio now have cases. Dr. Acton also reported that the CDC has added new COVID-19 Symptoms:

li.span: Chills
Shaking
Headache
Sore Throat
Loss of taste and smell

p.span: Governor DeWine announced the following:

li.span: Wearing a mask will not be mandatory for retail customers.
Citizen-based advisory groups for restaurants, barbershops, and salons are being coordinated to discuss reopening plans for those businesses.
Businesses should reference the amended updated Stay at Home Order to determine if they are able to reopen.
COVID-19 Update: Face Coverings, Advisory Groups on Restaurants, Barbershops, and Salons (Espanol)

hr.p: Today Governor DeWine stated the following about plans for Reopening Ohio:

ul.li: COVID-19 still presents a dangerous threat
Our tools to combat the threat will remain the same: social distancing, good hygiene practices, cleaning/sanitation, and the use of face coverings.
We will also expand testing and contact tracing efforts to ensure we can monitor and adjust as needed.
Those at high risk for severe disease should continue to practice caution.

hr.p: Proposed dates for Phase 1 of reopening are as follows:

May 1: Healthcare, including elective procedures that can be done and don’t require an overnight hospital stay. (Non-elective procedures that include overnight stays continue to be allowed.) Dental and Veterinary Offices may re-open.
May 4: Manufacturing, Distribution, Construction, and General Offices
May 12: Consumer/Retail Services

ul.li: The Stay at Home Order will be amended to allow for those returning to work and to patronize re-opening businesses
All businesses/workplaces that are open will have to maintain safety for workers and clients
Gatherings will continue to be limited to 10 people or fewer
Salons and Restaurants are not in Phase 1

li.a: Governor DeWine Announces Details of Ohio’s Responsible RestartOhio Plan

hr.p: No 2:00 p.m. press conference today.
As of 2:00 p.m., Ohio had 15,963 cases and 728 deaths from COVID-19.
No 2:00 p.m. press conference today.
As of 2:00 p.m., Ohio had 15,587 cases and 711 deaths from COVID-19.

p.span: To date, Ohio has 15,169 cases in 87 counties and 690 deaths due to COVID-19.
Governor DeWine made the following announcements on the 2:00 press conference:

li.span: Over the next three months, the State of Ohio will cover extended care for those in the Foster Care system who are turning 18 and aging out of the system.
Going forward, new data regarding prisons will be released every Tuesday.

Testing capacity has been limited in Ohio due to shortage of reagent and testing swabs. Ohio has a new partnership with Thermo Fisher, who has an FDA Approved reagent, and Roe Dental laboratory in Cleveland to produce swabs, which will bring 100 employees back to work.

p.span: Dr. Mark Hurst of the Ohio Department of Health discussed a new contact tracing program that will be supported by Partners in Health. Approximately 1,750 additional staff will be trained to support contact tracing efforts.

ul.li: COVID-19 Update: Reagent and Testing Swabs, Contact Tracing, Foster Care (Espanol)

p.span: Governor DeWine announced that Ohio has 14,694 cases and 656 deaths due to COVID-19 in Ohio.
Governor DeWine discussed criteria for hospital surgeries and procedures, which includes allowing procedures in situations where:

li.span: There is a threat to a patient’s life
There is a threat of permanent extremity/organ dysfunction
There is a risk of worsening disease or condition
There is a risk of rapidly worsening to severe symptoms

p.span: Governor DeWine also noted that there will be an announcement related to reopening on Monday, April 27th.

span.a: COVID-19 Update: How Environmental Changes Impact Health Risk

p.span: Dr. Acton reported that Ohio has 14,117 cases in 87 counties and 610 deaths due to COVID-19.
Governor DeWine reported:

li.span: The first case was reported by the Ohio Department of Youth Services.
A revised Executive Order regarding elective surgeries will be released. The revised order will provide additional detail and clarification.
There will be more information on the expansion of testing tomorrow.

p.span: Lori Criss of the Ohio Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services announced a new confidential COVID-19 Care line, 1(800)720-9616 to speak with licensed counselors 7 days a week from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. After 8:00 p.m., this line will transfer to the National Suicide Prevention Line.

li.span: COVID-19 Update: Elective Surgery Order, Mental Health CareLine (Espanol)

hr.p: Dr. Acton reported that Ohio has 13,725 cases in 87 counties and 557 deaths due to COVID-19. Dr. Acton spoke about a two part plan for reopening, including contact tracing and a gradual return to normalcy while weighing risk an benefit, re-opening lower risk activities first, and continually assessing the situation to determine how the virus is spreading and what actions are appropriate to take when.
Governor DeWine reported several updates:

ul.li: A new reagent has received FDA Approval and should greatly expand testing capabilities by mid-May.
A testing strike team will be led by former Ohio Governors Bob Taft and Richard Celeste.

No decisions have been made yet regarding county fairs. Funds have been budgeted for support, and Ohio Department of Agriculture will waive the match requirement for the fair grant program. Applications will remain open until May 30th.
COVID-19 Update: FDA Reagent Approval, Testing Strike Team, Fair Wavier, JobsOhio Banking Partnership, Dividend Checks (Espanol)

hr.p: Dr. Acton reported that Ohio has 12,919 cases in 87 counties and 509 deaths due to COVID-19. The relatively large increase over the weekend is in part due to intensive testing efforts.
Governor DeWine provided several updates:

ul.li: The remainder of this school year will be conducted remotely. It is ptoo early to make decisions about the 2020-2021 school year at this time.
There has been a greater impact of COVID-19 on the African-American community observed nationally, and a Minority Health Strike Force has been formed to work on this.
LabCorp and Quest have worked through their testing backlogs, and hospitals may send tests there again.
Ohio Department of Health has established a number of dashboards for viewing COVID-19 data. Protected Health Information that could potentially be used to identify individuals will not be reported.

Due to reporting issues, the nursing home and assisted living facility information posted last week has been taken down while corrections are made. This information will be updated on Wednesday, April 22 at 2:00 p.m. and Wednesdays at 2:00 p.m. moving forward. This data will include total cases to date for staff and residents, as well as new cases since last report. Information on deaths will be reported at the county level.
COVID-19 Update: K-12 Schools to Remain Closed, Minority Health Strike Force, Data Collection, Private Lab Testing (Espanol)
Minority Health Strike Force
Rescinding Director’s Order for COVID-19 Testing

p.span: No 2:00 p.m. press conference today.
To date, Ohio has 11,602 cases in 87 counties and 471 deaths due to COVID-19. Lake County has 133 cases and 6 deaths reported to date.

hr.p: Older updates, dating back to March 9, 2020 can be found in our archives under the “Daily Updates” tab.

div.p: Updates on LCGHD activities related to COVID-19 will be posted here as they are published. Older Situation Reports, dating back to March 12, 2020 can be found in our archives under the “Situation Reports” tab.

p.em: Please note that as of April 10, 2020, the Ohio Department of Health changed reporting of numbers to include both laboratory-confirmed cases and probable cases due to a change in the CDC case definition for COVID-19. The following reports include only confirmed cases, so numbers may not match total numbers reported elsewhere.

p.span: March 27, 2020 – Lake County Confirms its First Death Related to COVID-19

br.span: March 17, 2020 – Lake County Confirms its First Case of COVID-19
March 16, 2020 – Update on COVID-19 from Lake County Board of Health
March 13, 2020 – Update on COVID-19 from Lake County Board of Health
March 12, 2020 – Update on COVID-19 from Lake County Board of Health

div.p: Below are some frequently asked questions about 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19):

p.span: The Ohio Stay at Home Order (Espanol) went into effect at 11:59 p.m. on Monday, March 23, 2020, and was extended through 11:59 p.m. on Friday, May 1, 2020, unless amended.
Please see here for FAQs regarding the Stay at Home Order. (Espanol)
Please see here for highlights of the (original) Stay at Home Order. (Espanol)

li.span: For information on essential activities, please see Section 5 of the order.

For information on essential workforce, businesses, and operations, please see Section 12 of the order. For further guidance on essential workforce, please see the Homeland Security CISA Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response.

div.p: Additional Stay at Home Order resources and information can be found here.

p.span:
How can I report concerns about compliance with the Stay at Home Order?
Concerns about compliance with the Stay at Home Order may be reported to COVID19@lcghd.org or (440)350-2188. Those who wish to remain anonymous are encouraged to report by phone.
Due to an increased volume of inquiries, and the need to consult with Ohio Department of Health and legal expertise, it may take up to 48 hours to respond and/or resolve a complaint.
We appreciate your continued patience during this challenging time.

span.strong: Where can I find information on decisions made by the Dispute Resolution Commission for essential vs. non-essential businesses?

p.span: The Dispute Resolution Commission posts decisions and the minutes of their meetings here. Decisions are posted under the Advisory Opinions tab. A link for request forms to submit a dispute resolution request is located in the menu on the left side of the page.

Who can order a test for COVID-19?
Only a healthcare provider can order a test for COVID-19. Since tests are in limited supply, only very ill patients, or patients who are hospitalized will be tested for COVID-19 at this time. Samples are collected by a healthcare provider and are either processed by a hospital laboratory or sent to a laboratory for processing.

How is LCGHD notified of confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Lake County?
LCGHD receives new confirmed case information via ODRS (Ohio Disease Reporting System) electronically from laboratories conducting COVID-19 testing.

Is LCGHD the first organization notified when a Lake County resident tests positive for COVID-19?
Most of the time, but not always.

br.span: A person testing positive for COVID-19 may be notified of their test results before LCGHD is notified via the Ohio Disease Reporting System. That person could begin notifying friends, family and people they have come in contact with before LCGHD receives information about their positive test result. That information can spread quickly in our small community. As soon as LCGHD is aware of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19, we make contact with them immediately.

p.span:
What does LCGHD do when notified of a positive case of COVID-19?
When notified or made aware of a confirmed case, LCGHD will contact the person who tested positive. We ask questions about their illness, where they have been, and who they have come in contact with during the past 14 days. Our next step is called contact tracing. We contact, businesses, and individuals who may have been in contact with the individual. Based on the type of contact, we give advice on what the appropriate next steps are for the contacts to take. Generally, the recommendation is self-quarantine for 14 days with self-monitoring of temperature and signs and symptoms.

Is this why some organizations and businesses have notified their clients/patrons of possible COVID-19 exposure?
Yes. Once a business or organization is notified of a possible exposure, LCGHD will work with them to determine if other actions are necessary. Sanitation procedures will be reviewed and client/employee notifications are made.

p.br: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses which may cause illness in animals or humans. In humans, several coronaviruses are known to cause respiratory infections ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). The most recently discovered coronavirus causes coronavirus disease COVID-19.
COVID-19 is the infectious disease caused by the most recently discovered coronavirus. This new virus and disease were unknown before the outbreak began in Wuhan, China, in December 2019.

p.strong: What is the source of COVID-19?
p.br: COVID-19 likely came from an animal because the first cases were linked to a large seafood and animal market, suggesting a possible zoonotic origin to the outbreak. However, more information is needed to figure out the possible role that animals may play in transmission of COVID-19.

p.strong: What are the symptoms and complications of COVID-19?
p.br: Most people confirmed to have COVID-19 infection have had severe acute respiratory illness with symptoms of:

ul.li: Fever
Cough
Shortness of breath
Sore throat

li.span: Chills
Shaking
Headache
Loss of taste and smell

span.strong: What should I do if I have symptoms of COVID-19?

br.span: If you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 and develop a fever and symptoms, such as cough or difficulty breathing, call your healthcare provider for medical advice and what you should do next. Avoid contact with others.

p.br: People can catch COVID-19 from others who have the virus. The disease can spread from person to person through small droplets from the nose or mouth which are spread when a person with COVID-19 coughs or exhales. These droplets land on objects and surfaces around the person. Other people then catch COVID-19 by touching these objects or surfaces, then touching their eyes, nose or mouth. People can also catch COVID-19 if they breathe in droplets from a person with COVID-19 who coughs out or exhales droplets. This is why it is important to stay more than 6 feet away from other people to reduce the spread.

p.span:
What is community spread?
Community spread means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.

p.strong: Can COVID-19 be caught from a person who has no symptoms?
p.br: The main way the disease spreads is through respiratory droplets expelled by someone who is coughing. The risk of catching COVID-19 from someone with no symptoms at all is very low. However, many people with COVID-19 experience only mild symptoms. This is particularly true at the early stages of the disease. It is therefore possible to catch COVID-19 from someone who has, for example, just a mild cough and does not feel ill.

p.strong: Have there been cases in the United States (U.S.)?
p.br: Cases have been reported in all 50 states. Please refer to the CDC’s Situation Summary for the most current information.

p.strong: Am I at risk for COVID-19?
p.span: There is community spread of COVID-19 in many parts of the U.S., including Ohio and Lake County. Governor DeWine and Ohio Department of Health Director Dr. Amy Acton have issued a Stay at Home Order which currently remains in effect through 11:59 p.m. on May 1, 2020. This order means everyone has to stay at their home or place of residence, unless for necessary activities.

div.p: To lower your risk of catching any respiratory illness, remember to:

ul.li: Wash your hands for 20 seconds or more with soap and water. If unavailable, use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid contact with people who are sick.
Stay at home while you are sick (except to visit a healthcare provider) and avoid close contact with others.
Cover your mouth/nose with a tissue or sleeve when coughing or sneezing.
Get adequate sleep and eat well-balanced meals to ensure a healthy immune system.

p.strong: Who is at higher risk for severe illness?
p.br: While we are still learning about how COVID-2019 affects people, older persons and persons with pre-existing medical conditions (such as high blood pressure, heart disease, lung disease, cancer or diabetes) appear to develop serious illness more often than others. Please see CDC’s recommendations for those at higher risk.

span.strong: I am young and healthy. Why do I need to stay home?

br.span: COVID-19 is very contagious. You could become infected and pass it to someone with a compromised immune system who could experience very severe illness .

div.p:
How can I help prevent the spread of COVID-19?
COVID-19 is now spreading in the community. The best thing you can do to prevent the spread of COVID-19 is to stay home as much as possible. The spread of COVID-19 can also be prevented through basic preventive measures for all infectious respiratory diseases, including the following:

ul.li: Avoid contact with others who are sick.
Stay home if you are sick.
Do not travel while sick.
Call before visiting your doctor.
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleeve (not your hands) when coughing or sneezing.
Wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Dry hands with a clean towel or air dry your hands. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer if soap and water are not available.
Avoid touching your face, eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
Practice good hygiene habits.
Get adequate sleep and eat well-balanced meals.

p.span:
Should I wear a face mask to prevent the spread of COVID-19?
CDC recommends wearing cloth face coverings in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain (e.g., grocery stores and pharmacies), especially in areas of significant community-based transmission.

The cloth face coverings recommended are not surgical masks or N-95 respirators. Those are critical supplies that must continue to be reserved for healthcare workers and other medical first responders, as recommended by current CDC guidance. More information and instructions for making homemade masks can be found here.

div.p:
How likely am I to get COVID-19?
Cases of COVID-19 and instances of community spread are being reported in Lake County. Be sure to comply with the Ohio Stay at Home Order and other social distancing guidelines. Cooperating with disease control efforts will reduce your risk of catching or spreading COVID-19.
COVID-19 outbreaks can be contained and transmission stopped, as has been shown in China and some other countries.

p.strong: Can I still travel to China or countries where COVID-19 cases have occurred?
p.br: Please refer to the CDC’s COVID-19 Travel Notices page for the most current information.
There is currently no vaccine to protect against COVID-19. The U.S. National Institutes of Health is exploring the possibility of developing one.

p.strong: Will the flu or pneumonia vaccines protect me against COVID-19?
p.br: No. Vaccines against pneumonia, such as pneumococcal vaccine and Haemophilus influenza type B (Hib) vaccine, do not provide protection against the new coronavirus. The virus is so new and different that it needs its own vaccine. Researchers are trying to develop a vaccine against COVID-19. Although these vaccines are not effective against COVID-19, vaccination against respiratory illnesses is still highly recommended to protect your health.

There is no specific antiviral treatment recommended for COVID-19 infection. Individuals with COVID-19 can seek medical care to help relieve symptoms. For severe cases, current treatment includes care to support vital organ functions.

div.p:
Is it safe to receive a letter or package from China or other outbreak areas?
Yes, it is safe. People receiving packages from China or other outbreak areas are not at risk of contracting the new coronavirus. From previous analysis, it is known that coronaviruses do not survive long on objects, such as letters or packages.

p.span:
Should I be concerned about pets or other animals and COVID-19?
At this time, there is no evidence that companion animals, including pets, can spread COVID-19 to people or that they might be a source of infection in the United States. To date, CDC has not received any reports of pets becoming sick with COVID-19 in the United States.

br.span: Pets have other types of coronaviruses that can make them sick, like canine and feline coronaviruses. These other coronaviruses cannot infect people and are not related to the current COVID-19 outbreak.

However, since animals can spread other diseases to people, it’s always a good idea to practice healthy habits around pets and other animals, such as washing your hands and maintaining good hygiene. For more information on the many benefits of pet ownership, as well as staying safe and healthy around animals including pets, livestock, and wildlife, visit CDC’s Healthy Pets, Healthy People website.
